title: 104_s1079
content: The "Comprehensive Charity Reform Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for charitable contributions to certain private charities assisting the poor in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code allows individuals a credit for qualified charitable contributions made to eligible charities, limited to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). A qualified charitable contribution is a cash donation to a qualified charity, with details of each contribution and recipient identified on the tax return. A qualified charity, as defined by the tax code, is an organization exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) and 501(a). It must be certified by the Secretary and primarily assist the poor. Additionally, it must distribute at least 85 percent of funds collected to other qualified charities. The tax code defines a qualified charity as an organization exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) and 501(a), certified by the Secretary, and primarily assisting the poor. It must distribute at least 85 percent of funds collected to other qualified charities. The organization must also meet minimum expense requirements, with 70 percent of annual expenses dedicated to poverty programs. The term 'poverty program expense' refers to expenses in providing program services, excluding management, general expenses, expenses for influencing legislation, fundraising, and legal services for individuals. An organization may elect to treat one or more programs as a separate entity for tax purposes. This requires maintaining separate accounting for these programs and ensuring that contributions are used only for those programs. An organization can choose to treat certain programs as separate entities for tax purposes, requiring separate accounting and ensuring contributions are used solely for those programs. Reporting requirements are adjusted for these separate programs, with specific details to be included in the organization's tax return if necessary. The organization must meet additional requirements for solicitation organizations, including maintaining separate accounting for revenues and expenses and disclosing administrative and fundraising costs. The credit for charitable contributions provided in lieu of deductions can be elected by taxpayers for any taxable year. Every qualified charity must provide copies of their annual return to individuals upon request at no charge, as defined in section 23(d) of the Code. Every qualified charity must provide copies of their annual return to individuals upon request without charge other than a reasonable fee for reproduction and mailing costs. Copies must be provided immediately if the request is made in person, or within 30 days if made other than in person. This requirement applies only during the 3-year period beginning on the filing date of the return requested. Additionally, each qualified charity must furnish percentages of various categories of expenses for the year divided by total expenses. Every qualified charity must provide copies of their annual return to individuals upon request without charge other than a reasonable fee for reproduction and mailing costs. Copies must be provided immediately if the request is made in person, or within 30 days if made other than in person. This requirement applies only during the 3-year period beginning on the filing date of the return requested. Additionally, each qualified charity must furnish percentages of various categories of expenses for the year divided by total expenses, including program services, management and general, fundraising, and payments to affiliates. A clerical amendment has been made to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made after the 90th day following the enactment of the Act in taxable years ending after that date. Deduction for charitable contributions will be allowed to individuals who do not itemize deductions. The amendment allows individuals who do not itemize deductions to take a direct charitable deduction under section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment allows individuals to take a direct charitable deduction under section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. SEC. 4 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude charitable contributions from the overall limitation on itemized deductions. This change applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow taxpayers to treat charitable contributions made before filing their tax return as if they were made on the last day of the taxable year. This election is irrevocable and applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Each applicable welfare program must publish information in the Federal Register and other public publications after each fiscal year, including expenses for program services, administrative costs, and fundraising. The program must also disclose the percentages of expenses for program services, management, general costs, and fundraising. The program must make subsection (a) information available at its offices and provide copies to individuals upon request. An applicable welfare program is a Federal, State, or local program receiving Federal funds. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on welfare programs to develop standards for determining their success in meeting established needs and cost-effectiveness. A report on the study's results, including the described standards, will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment.
